elements.2211.03281_a25a827e3af7ffa0b619530d7a50b: Recent advances in reinforcement-learning research have demonstrated impressive results in building algorithms that can out-perform humans in complex tasks
elements.2211.03281_bcd359a9db52130e407858e18dd58: Nevertheless, creating reinforcement-learning systems that can build abstractions of their experience to accelerate learning in new contexts still remains an active area of research.
elements.2211.03281_e9699f95ef543f99e368c9a3a280f: Previous work showed that reward-predictive state abstractions fulfill this goal, but have only be applied to tabular settings
elements.2211.03281_c834870c94963073f12a7b36ea4d5: Here, we provide a clustering algorithm that enables the application of such state abstractions to deep learning settings, providing compressed representations of an agent's inputs that preserve the ability to predict sequences of reward
elements.2211.03281_b1eca146e2522d011aba9b1d9a20f: A convergence theorem and simulations show that the resulting reward-predictive deep network maximally compresses the agent's inputs, significantly speeding up learning in high dimensional visual control tasks
elements.2211.03281_8093ca3d926fb607ae00be62a5047: Furthermore, we present different generalization experiments and analyze under which conditions a pre-trained reward-predictive representation network can be re-used without re-training to accelerate learning
elements.2211.03281_f92c5ea2b24cd3a6e203b79f77397: a form of systematic out-of-distribution transfer.
elements.2211.03281_37c27bc8b20208559705af25fc893: have demonstrated impressive results, outperforming humans on a range of different tasks
elements.2211.03281_e78a7046c93ab9456559cf67e89f2: Despite these advances, the problem of building systems that can re-use knowledge to accelerate learning
elements.2211.03281_4699655fb35636966fe83a98e061e: By incorporating previously learned knowledge into the process of finding a solution for a novel task, intelligent systems can speed up learning and make fewer mistakes
elements.2211.03281_d865ca941e31aef0303dd68b20288: Therefore, efficient knowledge re-use is a central, yet under-developed, topic in RL research
elements.2211.03281_4404a0fe4537152e2af0d07d64304: We approach this question through the lens of representation learning
elements.2211.03281_a3da1eb4ad9315148fb93d8495080: Here, an RL agent constructs a representation function to compress its high-dimensional observations into a lower-dimensional latent space
elements.2211.03281_4b7670975df3e041a10b1554f0bca: This representation function allows the system to simplify complex inputs while preserving all information relevant for decision-making
elements.2211.03281_2398d2254defde827f70ef1cf67a6: By abstracting away irrelevant aspects of task, an RL agent can efficiently generalize learned values across distinct observations, leading to faster and more data-efficient learning
elements.2211.03281_8b80773279bc79dd2dc98deab0ae0: Nevertheless, a representation function can become specialized to a specific task, and the information that needs to be retained often differs from task to task
elements.2211.03281_55c1fa6e3f4f0fe704c3ac68a3159: In this context, the question of how to compute an efficient and
elements.2211.03281_0cfd63cb9380052641b225b148cd1: In this article, we introduce a clustering algorithm that computes a reward-predictive representation
elements.2211.03281_b922ab1f301c984bf76c5fa9559fe: from a fixed data set of interactions
elements.2211.03281_cc750e249cc96633ee21a3833784d: A reward-predictive representation is a type of function that compresses high-dimensional inputs into lower-dimensional latent states
elements.2211.03281_460550ac49ed21bda3d8ca8e0fad5: These latent states are constructed such that they can be used to predict future rewards without having to refer to the original high dimensional input
elements.2211.03281_92f3ba5ec42f604efb5f22f421053: To compute such a representation, the clustering algorithm processes an interaction data set that is sampled from a single
elements.2211.03281_8c682395f80503e61a7e74d1e1d8b: First, every state observation is assigned to the same latent state index
elements.2211.03281_27eb709bca0bb4fa5ed22a529db55: Then, this single state cluster is iteratively refined by introducting additional latent state indices and re-assigning some state observations to them
elements.2211.03281_03bbd2d4213a94cacd49ec139111d: At the end, the assignment between state observations and latent state cluster indices can be used to train a representation network that classifies high-dimensional states into one of the computed latent state cluster
elements.2211.03281_8472e128bd09f2164731d35d817ca: Later on, the output of this representation network can be used to predict future reward outcomes without referring to the original high-dimensional state
elements.2211.03281_f14d557c441211a21c59a861c87ac: Therefore, the resulting representation network is a reward-predictive representation.
elements.2211.03281_c8715fad886d5bf84bb204a7c6fa8: The presented clustering algorithm is generic: Besides constraining the agent to decide between a finite number of actions, no assumptions about rewards or state transitions are made
elements.2211.03281_17354e4c24300e3fa7097ca553d20: We demonstrate that these reward-predictive representation networks can be used to accelerate learning in
elements.2211.03281_8be9a1f8dcbcafa6825c623399953: that differ in both transition and reward functions from those used in the training task
elements.2211.03281_10b3d476dc777c82e7fcc23c0c35f: The algorithm demonstrates a form of out-of-distribution generalization because the test tasks require learning a task solution that is novel to the RL agent and does not follow the training data's distribution
elements.2211.03281_24f13e858090300239e9195f4bd41: The simulation experiments reported below demonstrate that reward-predictive representation networks comprise a form of abstract knowledge re-use, accelerating learning to new tasks
elements.2211.03281_798cd2afd5470df69e5b4db5eb5ac: To unpack how reward-predictive representation networks can be learned and transferred, we first illustrate the clustering algorithm using different examples and prove a convergence theorem
elements.2211.03281_a911609e70b79527c92a83cadf5c7: Lastly, we present transfer experiments illuminating the question of when the learned representation networks generalize to test tasks that are distinct from the training task in a number of different properties.

elements.2211.03281_b50baf29540f085b43e9027319da7: Improving learning efficiency with successor representations
elements.2211.03281_cf95106782e975c1f099de0483bbf: To improve an RL agent's ability to generalize its predictions across states, the Successor Representation (SR) was introduced by
elements.2211.03281_cb5b8de453f02c041bc8dad4c1590: Instead of explicitly planning a series of transitions, the SR summarizes the frequencies with which an agent visits different future states as it behaves optimally and maximizes rewards
elements.2211.03281_ac5e33b1e273a620399d994d14c49: Because the SR models state visitation frequencies, this representation implicitly encodes the task's transition function and optimal policy
elements.2211.03281_1938b1ce98a0a99ef8e4385e4cdae: Consequently, the SR provides an intermediate between model-based RL, which focuses on learning a full model of a task's transition and reward functions, and model-free RL, which focuses on learning a policy to maximize rewards
elements.2211.03281_3856a6305ad3c3c6e95472355b9c5: showed that the SR can be generalized to Successor Features (SFs), which compress the high dimensional state space into a lower dimensional one that can still be used to predict future state occupancies
elements.2211.03281_ab09c0591153996d68a137edff04e: They demonstrated how SFs can be re-used across tasks with different reward functions to speed up learning
elements.2211.03281_65524d05148068d9efc546bf36f6f: only reflect the task's transition function and optimal policy but are invariant to any specifics of the reward function itself
elements.2211.03281_52939e7007161af45a2ae3f4ce24c: Because of this invariance, SFs provide an initialization allowing an agent to adapt a previously learned policy to tasks with different reward functions, leading to faster learning in a life-long learning setting
elements.2211.03281_7ed9d269b4a1b3a445233bde884d2: However, such transfer requires the optimal policy in the new task to be similar to that of the previous tasks
elements.2211.03281_88281f988e0e62182d0e2cfb7c80f: For example, even if only the reward function changes, but the agent had not typically visited states near the new reward location in the old task, the SR/SF is no longer useful and must be relearned from scratch
elements.2211.03281_4e3ebc1653c8d6eb227e60af2abec: To further improve the invariance properties of SFs,
elements.2211.03281_d66a13b5b1ef6ba2f40a299c7110f: presented a model that makes use of SFs solely for establishing which states are equivalent to each other for the sake of predicting future reward sequences, resulting in a reward-predictive representation

elements.2211.03281_967e54aeac022a2572ae5ec252fd1: While the reward-predictive representation network cannot be used to predict reward-sequences or event Q-values accurately, the Q-value predictions learned by the agent are sufficient to still find an optimal policy quickly in this test task
elements.2211.03281_9313d0545a67f1d02a8c8d5a29957: Of course, one could imagine test tasks where this is not the case and the agent would have to learn a new policy from scratch

elements.2211.03281_7e02fa5dbfc2be4101edd637a61f0: Because the representation network only encodes state equivalences, the network can be used across tasks with different transitions and rewards
elements.2211.03281_e309e4dc0fa6615bf47e30d4243b5: However, if different state equivalences are necessary for reward prediction in a test task, then it may or may not be possible to learn an optimal policy without modifying the representation network

elements.2211.03281_90aeb8032767bc3d4396a80a037bb: By starting with a single latent state and then iteratively introducing additional latent states to minimize SF prediction errors where necessary, the final number of latent states is minimized

elements.2211.03281_0d4b36a1dd36e621e6ad0d991fc64: The clustering algorithm computes a reward-predictive representation in a similar way, by first refining a state representation around changes in one-step rewards and subsequently bootstrapping from this representation to further refine the state clustering
elements.2211.03281_6a6cb56f3674a11246d6dabd581fb: This leads to a maximally compressed latent state space, which is important for abstracting away information from the state input and enabling an agent to efficiently generalize across states (as demonstrated by the generalization experiments in Section

elements.2211.03281_f69d907c380c78b1336258aa0452b: One assumption made in the presented experiments is that a task's state space can always be compressed into a small enough finite latent space
elements.2211.03281_78c0101a2855bda6ff10ff918fd66: This assumption is not restrictive, because any (discrete time) RL agent only observes a finite number of transitions and states at any given time point
elements.2211.03281_f6e5dee158890a016d6cdc67e9733: Consequently, all state observations can always be compressed into a finite number of latent states, similar to block MDPs
elements.2211.03281_329f9256a46037790728e8eba71d8: Furthermore, the presented method always learns a fully conjunctive representation
elements.2211.03281_57206b717160882245b6e8f1c51cf: In the combination-lock examples, the reward-predictive representation associates a different latent state (one-hot vector) with each relevant combination pattern
elements.2211.03281_4bcae164efd3b299383e83e0b6ce5: This representation is conjunctive because it does not model the fact that the dials rotate independently
elements.2211.03281_fb219910aa198b9c4bffa61c0c4f3: A disjunctive or factored representation could map each of the three dials independently into three separate latent state vectors and a concatenation of these vectors could be used to describe the task's latent state
elements.2211.03281_42d6c6b5f4fb7eb1c78fe4399397c: Such a latent representation is similar to factored representations used in prior work
elements.2211.03281_3f3d0baf938596d399aa285303846: and these factored representations permit a more compositional form of generalization across different tasks
elements.2211.03281_9e45f3b1140700214836f1884eeb3: How to extract such factored representations from unstructured state spaces such as images still remains a challenging problem
elements.2211.03281_8f7c2b07d0e140b51a2f9d8c70494: We leave such an extension to future work
elements.2211.03281_f9545b23b212cf2f9d210d0c83815: has focused on extracting an inductive bias from a set of tasks to accelerate learning in subsequent tasks
elements.2211.03281_d9ebd6fdbd022fb2877a26e8f3611: These methods transfer a value function or policy model to initialize and accelerate learning
elements.2211.03281_53593c8999160ca4754728645a0bf: Because these methods transfer a model of a task's policy, these models have to be adapted to each transfer task, if the transfer task's optimal policy differs from the previously learned policies
elements.2211.03281_81b9f490b789bc21a6012ee94e4fc: Reward-predictive representations overcome this limitation by only modelling how to generalize across different states
elements.2211.03281_ebeb33cb01de34547ca8bdee9c415: Because reward-predictive representations do not encode the specifics of how to transition between different latent states or how latent states are tied to rewards, these representations are robust to changes in transitions and rewards
elements.2211.03281_1ee45e856c113655a9b3723281d4a: Furthermore, the reward-predictive representation network is learned using a single task and the resulting network is sufficient to demonstrate positive transfer across different transitions and rewards
elements.2211.03281_fc76054e00e711154ca89fe2140e9: This form of transfer is also different from the method presented by
elements.2211.03281_b7e437cbed412e4fd9e468e27d2e2: , where the focus is on extracting a common task structure from a set of tasks instead of learning a representation from a single task and transferring it to different test tasks.
elements.2211.03281_1bbf2dd32fb3d0838047a4b50f092: Still, in a lifelong learning scenario, re-using the same reward-predictive representation network to solve every task may not be possible because an agent may have to generalize across different states (as demonstrated by the left dial broken combination lock variant in Section
elements.2211.03281_f9e116b512da2dff7a5dd18a577c3: In this article, we analyze the generalization properties of reward-predictive representations through A-B transfer experiments
elements.2211.03281_4a04a279ff45ae126594b1af1764b: already present a (non-parametric) meta-learning model that uses reward-predictive representations to accelerate learning in finite MDPs, we leave how to integrate the presented clustering algorithm into existing meta-learning frameworks commonly used in deep RL
elements.2211.03281_44622f7fd04957836a435b10c9b29: We presented a clustering algorithm to compute reward-predictive representations that introduces as few latent states as possible
elements.2211.03281_9b77f64a073451df0e7f622c5c923: The algorithm works by iteratively refining a state representation using a temporal difference error that is defined on state features
elements.2211.03281_6d1daa3d18e8c7aef3c8879348836: Furthermore, we analyze under which assumptions the resulting representation networks are suitable for systematic out-of-distribution generalization and demonstrate that reward-predictive representation networks enable RL agents to re-use abstract task knowledge to improve their learning efficiency.
